title: FirstFT: Western leaders unite ahead of Biden-Putin call
text:
Click here to listen to the latest news in less than three minutes. Top Stories Today is an audio news digest that gets you up to speed on the day's headlines.

Western powers presented a united front on the eve of a phone call between Joe Biden and Vladimir Putin, when the US president is expected to detail punitive measures that would inflict “severe” damage to Russia's economy if the country invades Ukraine.

The US president hosted talks with the leaders of France, Germany, Italy and the UK last night, during which they discussed ratcheting up economic sanctions against the Kremlin should it launch a Ukraine invasion, according to White House officials.

However, the officials said the Biden administration was not planning “direct use of American military force” in the event of a Russian invasion.

Antony Blinken, US secretary of state, also spoke with Volodymyr Zelensky, Ukraine's president, yesterday and reiterated Washington's “unwavering support for Ukraine's sovereignty”.

The Biden administration has warned western allies that Russia could launch a military invasion of Ukraine in early 2022, in a potential deepening of a conflict that began with Moscow's annexation of Crimea in 2014.

Moscow has blamed the west for fuelling tensions by funding the modernisation of Ukraine's army and accused Nato of provoking it by adding new member states closer to Russia's borders. It wants a legally binding commitment that Ukraine will not join Nato — a guarantee the US refuses to grant.

“The stakes couldn't be higher,” said Samuel Charap, a Russia expert at the Rand Corporation, a US-based think-tank, ahead of the Biden-Putin call.

Read more

Opinion: Putin insists that Ukraine is a failed state being led astray by scheming foreigners, writes Gideon Rachman.

The FT View: Biden must show that further aggression against Ukraine would be met with sanctions that would impose an intolerable cost on Russia.

Global Insight: Russia lands Germany's new chancellor Olaf Scholz with his first foreign policy test, writes Ben Hall.

Are you worried about a possible invasion of Ukraine by Russia? Email me at firstft@ft.com. Thanks for reading FirstFT Americas. Here's the rest of today's news — Gordon

Five more stories in the news

1. US regulators probe Donald Trump's social media Spac deal The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating Digital World Acquisition Corp, the blank-cheque company set to merge with Donald Trump's social media start-up, seeking information on trading before the deal was announced as well as dealings between the two groups.

2. Evergrande edges closer to a formal default Investors in China Evergrande say they have not received crucial bond payments after the expiry of a 30-day grace period yesterday. The company, which has delayed several international bond payments, had $82.5m in coupons due on Monday — days after it signalled the need to restructure its debt.

3. Samsung launches management shake-up Four months after being released from prison, Samsung heir Lee Jae-yong has reshuffled his management as the group steps up its push into non-memory chips and artificial intelligence. The shake-up included merging the group's consumer electronics and mobile divisions to take on competitor Apple.

4. Saudi Aramco warns of ‘social unrest' if fossil fuels ditched The chief executive of Saudi Aramco, the world's largest oil producer, has called on global leaders to continue investing in fossil fuels or run the risk of spiralling inflation and “social unrest”. The comments by Amin Nasser come amid growing investor and social pressure for fossil fuel companies to make their operations greener.

4. Wall Street traders' growing sway in Bitcoin market Bitcoin's rocky weekend marked one of the first times a storm in traditional financial assets triggered big waves in cryptocurrencies, underscoring how large investors are playing an increasingly important role in digital asset markets.

5. China denounces US boycott of Beijing Winter Olympics China's foreign ministry has denounced the Biden administration's decision to boycott the Beijing Winter Olympics, which begin in February. A spokesman for China's foreign ministry said crimes committed by the US against native Americans and not China's persecution of Muslim Uyghurs in Xinjiang “are the real genocide”.

Coronavirus digest

  • Foreign embassies in Seoul, including those of the US and the UK, have called on the South Korean government to grant “urgent recognition” of foreign nationals vaccinated overseas against Covid-19.

  • European Central Bank policymakers are reassessing their commitment to extra stimulus, reflecting rising doubts about how quickly inflation will fall as the Omicron coronavirus variant fuels worries of further price rises.

  • Early data from a hospital in South Africa showed that on December 2 only nine of 42 patients in the Covid-19 ward were being treated and needed oxygen, suggesting the Omicron coronavirus variant could result in less severe illness.

  • New York City will require all private sector workers to be vaccinated — the strictest vaccine mandate in the US.

The day ahead

Economic data The US trade deficit in goods and services is expected to have narrowed to $66.8bn in October, from a record $80.9bn the previous month, thanks to a surge in exports, the commerce department is expected to say.

Holmes returns to the stand Elizabeth Holmes' criminal fraud trial is scheduled to resume, with the Theranos founder expected to return to the stand for cross examination. Holmes faces 11 counts of wire fraud and conspiracy to commit wire fraud, each of which carries a maximum prison sentence of 20 years.

EU publishes gig economy rules Gig economy companies will be forced to prove that their workforces are self-employed contractors, not employees, for the first time under new draft legislation due to be published by the European Commission.

UK travel restrictions All arrivals to the UK, regardless of their vaccination status, will be required to show proof of a negative pre-departure coronavirus test from today.

Pearl Harbor anniversary Today marks 80 years since Japan bombed Pearl Harbor. Expect substantial analysis of relations between the countries, which have improved significantly since Shinzo Abe became the first Japanese prime minister to visit the site five years ago.

What else we're reading

The next quant revolution Corporate credit has been largely untouched by computer-driven trading. But a new breed of money managers is hoping to shake up the market using processing power, models, algorithms and big data to systematically wring cash out of pricing anomalies.

La Niña to intensify extreme weather The weather pattern, which has developed for the second consecutive year, is expected to intensify rainfall as well as droughts around the world with a continuing effect on agriculture and water supply.

Honduras is the new front in US-China struggle over Taiwan While Taipei celebrates support from Japan and the west, Taiwanese diplomats worry over Honduras's allegiance — one of the few countries with whom they maintain diplomatic ties. A tug of war between the US and China for influence in Central America hangs over the shifting relationship.

The race to go electric A transformation is under way in the auto industry as batteries replace the internal combustion engine. From behind the wheel of the latest models, FT reporters talk about the cars, the technology and the companies and countries that will come out on top.

Wealth

As part of the FT Financial Literacy and Inclusion Campaign, musician Courtney Love shares her story about making and losing a fortune: “My family has been the victim of every single financial crime there is”, she writes.
